div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter Cents Per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div4.head: Mr. Vallandigham and the Ohio Governorship.
div4.p:
The telegraphic reports have stated that Mr. Vallandigham had been nominated as the Democratic candidate for Governor of Ohio.
This is not the case.
The State Convention has not yet assembled.
Mr. Vallandigham, however, is generally spoken of in connection with the nomination, and will, we presume, be placed authoritatively before the people.
We find the following letter consenting to the use of his name, in our late Ohio exchanges:

dateline.name: House of Representatives, Washington City, D. C.,

opener.salute:
David F. Cable, Esq., Stubenville, Ohio:
My Dear Sir:

div5.p: I have received your letter on behalf of the central committee of Jefferson county, stating that "it has been extensively circulated that I wholly refuse to run for the nomination" as Democratic candidate for Governor of Ohio, next fail, and inquiring as to my position in regard to it. In answer, I would say that the desire has been freely and cordially expressed to me from all parts of the State that my name may be used in Convention for that purpose, and I have yielded to the wishes of my friends.

My name, therefore, will be presented to the Democratic State Convention in connection with that office; and if it be the belief of the Democracy of the State, as expressed in that Convention, that I may be able, in the position, to aid and hasten the reunion of these States and, therefore, the return of the prosperity and blenings of other and better times, and their desire, also, that I shall be their candidate, no honorable exertion, however great, shall be omitted by me in the canvass to have the nomination ratified through the ballot box by a triumphant election.
Having clung to the old ship when the storm raged fiercest, and clouds were blackest, and friends fewest, I will not desert her now, when upon a smoother sea and with gentler and more prosperous winds around her.
Satisfied, however, that the Convention will, in any event, act wisely and soundly, I shall yield a cordial and active support to the choice of that Convention, whoever he may be.
Thanking my friends in Jefferson for their kindly feelings, as expressed in your letter.

div4.head: The "on to Richmond" movement — more developments.
div4.p: The court-martial on the case of McDowell, in Washington, brought out some highly interesting facts about the "On to Richmond" movement.--The following papers elicited will be found very engaging to the reader's attention:

div5.head:
Executive Mansion,
Washington, March 8th, 1862.
div5.p: Ordered, that no change of the base of operations of the Army of the Potomac shall be made without leaving in and about Washington such a force as, in the opinion of the General-in-Chief and the commanders of all the army corps, shall leave said city entirely secure.

That no more than two army corps (about fifty thousand troops) of said Army of the Potomac shall be moved en route for a new base of operations until the navigation of the Potomac, from Washington to the Chesapeake Bay, shall be freed from enemy's batteries and other obstructions, or until the President shall hereafter give express permission.

That any movements as aforesaid en route for a new base of operations, which may be ordered by the General-in-Chief, and which may be intended to move upon the Chesapeake Bay, shall begin to move upon the Bay as early as the 18th day of March instant, and the General-in-Chief shall be responsible that it so move as early as that day.
Ordered, that the army and navy co-operate in an immediate effort to capture the enemy's batteries upon the Potomac, between Washington and the Chesapeake Bay.
That order led to a conference of the General officers commanding the Army Corps--the report of which conference is dated March 13, and is as follows:

div5.head:
Headq'rs Army of the Potomac,
Fairfax Court-House, March 13, 1862.
div5.p: A council of the Generals commanding Army Corps at the Headquarters of the Army of the Potomac were of the opinion:

list.item:
I. That the enemy having retreated from Manassas to Gordonsville, behind the Rappahannock and Repidan, it is the opinion of the Generals commanding Army Corps that the operations to be carried on will be best undertaken from Old Point Comfort, between the York and James Rivers, upon Richmond, provided,
1.
That the enemy's vessel, the Merrimac, can be neutralized.
2. That the means of transportation sufficient for an immediate transfer of the force to its new base can be ready at Washington and Alexandria to move down the Potomac, and
3.
That a naval auxiliary force can be had to silence, or aid in allencing, the enemy's batteries in York river.
4.
That the force to be left to cover Washington shall be such as to give an entire feeling of security for its safety from menace.
Unanimous.

II.
If the foregoing cannot be, the army should then be moved against the enemy behind the Rappahannock, at the earliest possible moment, and the means for reconstructing bridges, repairing railroads, and stocking them with material sufficient for supplying the army, should at once be collected for both the Orange and Alexandria and the Aquila and Richmond Railroads.

div5.p: [Note.--That with the forts on the right bank of the Potomac fully garrisoned, and those on the left bank occupied, a covering force in front of the Virginia line of 25,000 men would suffice.
A total of 40,000 men for the defence of the city would suffice.
The plan alluded to in that paper drew from the War Department, from Mr. Stanton, Secretary of War, communicating the order of the President, the following paper, dated March 13, 1862:

div5.head: War Department, March 13, 1862.

p.hi: To Major Gen. Geo. B. McClellan:

div5.p: The President having considered the plan of operations agreed upon by yourself and the commanders of army corps, makes no objection to the same, but gives the following directions as to its execution:

list.item:
1.
Leave such force at Manassas Junction as shall make it entirely certain that the enemy shall not repossess himself of that position and line of communication.
2. Leave Washington entirely secure.

3. Move the remainder of the force down the Potomac, choosing a new base at Fortress Monroe, or anywhere between here and there; or, at all events, move such remainder of the army at once in pursuit of the enemy, by some route.
Seven o'clock, forty minutes.

closer.signed: Edwin M. Stanton, Sec'y of War.

div5.p: The order just read recites the conditions in the order of the President of the 8th of March under which the new base of operations might be taken up. This repetition of the conditions shows the importance attached to them by the President.
After Gen. McClellan left the front of Washington it was observed in the War Department that his orders for the movement of the troops did not appear to contemplate leaving.

div5.head:
Headq'rs Mil'ry Dis. Of Washington,
Washington, D. C., April 2, 1862.

p.hi: To the Hon. Secretary of War:

div5.p: Sir — I have the honor to submit the following condensed statement of the forces left under my command for the defence of Washington:

row.cell: Deduct sick, and in arrest and confinement

div5.p:
I have no Mounted Light Artillery under my command.
Several companies of the Reserve Artillery of the Army of the Potomac are still here, but not under my command or fit for service.

From this force I am ordered by Gen. McClellan to detail two regiments (good ones) to Richardson's division, (Sumner's corps) as it passes through Alexandria; one regiment to replace the 27th N. Y. volunteers, in Heintzelman's old division; one regiment to relieve a regiment of Hooker's division, at Budd's Ferry — total, four regiments.
I am also further ordered this morning, by telegraph, to send 4,000 men to relieve Gen. Sumner at Manassas and Warrenton that he may embark forthwith.

In regard to the character and efficiency of the troops under my command, I have to state that nearly all the force is new and imperfectly disciplined — that several of the regiments are in a very disorganized condition from various causes, which it is not necessary to state here.
Several regiments having been relieved from brigades which have gone into the field, in consequence of their unfitness for service, the best regiments remaining having been selected to take their place.
Two heavy artillery regiments, and one infantry regiment, which had been drilled for some months in artillery service, have been withdrawn from the forts on the South side of the Potomac, and I have only been able to $1 their places with very new infantry regiments, entirely unacquainted with the duties of that arm, and of little or no value in their present position.

I am not informed of the position which Major Gen. Banks is directed to take, but at this time he is as I understand, on the other side of the Bull Run mountains, leaving my command to cover the front from Manassas Gap (about twenty miles beyond Manassas) to Aquila Creek.

I deem it my duty to state that looking at the numerical strength and character of the force under my command, it is in my judgment entirely inadequate to and unfit for the important duty to which it is assigned.

I regard it very improbable that the enemy will assail us at this point; but this belief is based upon the hope that they may be promptly engaged elsewhere, and may not learn the number and character of the force left here.

closer.salute: I have the honor to be your obd't serv't,

div4.head: Copy of a Paper handed to the President by General Hitchcock.
div4.p: The main line of the enemy extends from Richmond, through Chattanooga and Corinth, to Memphis, and at Corinth there is a connection South.

Gen. Halleck (at St. Louis) is acting upon the west of this line; with Gen. Buell as his immediate commander, having Corinth in view as one object, and some point at or near the Cumberland Gap as another object.
Gen. McClellan (before York town) has Richmond for his object, with Washington under his safekeeping.
The immediate interest of the war is connected with the above operations and all adjacent operations are incidental.
It is necessary to break the line of communication between Richmond and Corinth.
This may be done by Buell; and if he should occupy the Cumberland Gap, near the railroad, this object will be sufficiently accomplished.
If some point east of the Gap be also made an object, (as proposed by the President,) it will require a large force to reach and maintain it, or that force might be destroyed by the enemy.

Instead, therefore, of employing a force necessary for seizing a point east of the Gap, it might be better to employ a less force in the protection of the Baltimore and Ohio railroad--the duty assigned to Gen. Fremont.

From present indications it might be better, instead of sending to the Mountain Department all of the force desired by its commander, to divide that force--one part to go to him for the protection of the Baltimore and Ohio railroad, and the country immediately south of it, and the other part to strengthen McClellan's right, now occupied by Shields; the route from Richmond in that direction being open to the enemy, who, though not likely to take it, might be invited by its weakness to make some desperate attempt similar to one already made by Jackson upon Shields.

A movement from McClellan's left is known to the enemy; hence, nothing is more natural than a blow on McClellan's right.
Nothing has intervened since that made a few days since to prevent a repetition of it with a larger force.

If McClellan should fail at York town — not likely to happen — but if he should fail, what would be the movement of the enemy?
It might be a desperate attempt to turn the right of the Army of the Potomac--the Shenandoah Valley.

This should be guarded against by a part of the force called for by Fremont, instead of sending that force to cut the Richmond and Knoxville Railroad--the success of which might even aid in forcing the enemy to make some desperate attempt on the right of Washington.

This effort on my part failed, and that division left the Shenandoah Valley. General Banks had been ordered into the Valley on account of the attack that had been made by Jackson upon Shields.
This still further reduced the force in front of Washington.
I ought, perhaps, to state that Blenker did not leave the Valley for some weeks.
He was under orders which I could not succeed in having revoked and therefore his force could not be counted on for the defence of Washington.
I had these particulars in my mind in signing the joint report with Gen Thomas.
I considered, further, that the opinion of the four commanders of the corps d armes, setting forth the form necessary for the defence of Washington, was confined to the city and its defences on the other side of the river, extending as far as Manassas and Warrenton, and that front in general, but that it did not include the forces in the Valley of the Shenandoah; and that the troops in the Valley could not be withdrawn without subjecting the National cause to great danger, was my clear and decided opinion.
Looking therefore, to the troops that might be counted on for the defence of Washington, I could not make out 25,000 as a unity force, including the garrisons of the forts South of the river, after allowing the usual deductions for the sick, &c.

When these reports came before the President he was manifestly under great anxiety.
It was his declared wish to give to Gen McClellan all the force he called for, and all the means that could be thrown into his hands to enable him to execute his purpose; but finally, after much consideration, he determined to order one of the two remaining corps — then in front of Washington — to be detained here, leaving the selection with the Secretary of War, who designated the corps commanded by Gen. McDowell.
As soon as this was reported to Gen. McClellan he complained of it as an interference with his command, calculated to lead to the most dangerous consequences.
He asked for two of the three divisions constituting that corps — Franklin's and McClell's — and if he could not get the two, he was particularly anxious to have Franklin's division.
The President came to the War Office in person, and held a discussion of some length with several of the Chiefs of Bureaus in the War Department, in the presence of the Secretary of War.
I cannot, from memory, recite particulars of that discussion.
I was present and heard it. Some opinions were averse to sending any part of that force to the Peninsula.
I think that one--and one only — officer was in favor of sending the whole of it. At length the President asked me individually if I thought the city would be safe with the two divisions if Franklin should be sent away.
I replied that I thought it would be safe.
He then wrote the order for Gen. Franklin's division to go to Gen. McClellan. Gen. McDowell was not present at this discussion.

div3.head: European Gossip.
div3.p: In the latest register of French loves and conjugal disasters it is stated that the youthful bride of a well-known banker's son-in-law, who had elope-with the Receiver-General of Tours, has returned from her little journey perfectly disgusted with the experiment, and perfectly restored to her sense of duty and affection for her husband by the singular wit displayed by the latter, which showed at once his superiority over the man for whom she had deserted him:

"At the moment of elopement the gay Lotharic wrote a line to the injured husband, giving notice of the destination the fugitives were about to seek, and offering to bestow any reparation of honor which the husband might choose to demand; whereupon the latter immediately dispatched an envelope, containing ten bank notes of a thousand francs each, with a short, pithy letter, saying that as he knew by sad experience the extravagant habits of his fair traveling companion, he was afraid, last for want of funds, he might be induced to turn back — and begging his acceptance of the sum mentioned, to meet some little portion of the expenses he had entailed upon himself by association with such a terrible spendthrift as the fair lady he had chosen.
The laugh is wholly on the side of the husband, while the poor victorious lover sneaks about great-fallen, having lost place, preferment, honor and reputation."

One of the examiners of the Statistical Society of London came to a house in Mariebone in which there was one remarkable room.
It was occupied not by one family, but by five.
A separate family ate drank, and slept in each of the four corners of this room; a fifth in the centre. "How can you exist?" said the visitor to a poor woman whom he had found in the room, (the other inmates being absent on their several avocations,) "how can you possibly exist?" "Oh, indeed, your honor." she replied, "we did very well until the gentleman in the middle took a lodger."

At Baron Rothschilds's fete at Ferrieres, it is said (among other waggeries) that a parrot, carefully trained to utter one particular phrase, was 1st loose somewhere directly in range of the Emperor's fowling piece; the imperial marksman fired and hit, and the loyal bird gave out his last spasm of life in the devoted cry of 'Vive T. Empereur! '

Her Majesty having commanded that the nuptials of His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales and the Princess Alexandria of Denmark shall be celebrated with great magnificence, preparations have been commenced by the employees of the Lord Chamberlain's department at Windsor Castle with that view.

A number of extra hands have been engaged, and the work in the State departments and other parts of the castle is making rapid progress under the superintendence of Mr. W. Seabrook, her Majesty's inspector, assisted by Messrs. Miles, Bently & Co. The State apartments are being furnished with the superb hangings which were used during the visit of the Emperor and Empress of the French in 1855 and the Zuccarelli room is undergoing a complete change.
The whole of the furniture, picture frames, mouldings, and the panel frames are being richly reglit, while the walls were being hung with costly Italian silk, six feet in width, bearing the initials "V. R." en circled with a wreath and ornamented with a crown, the silk being similar to that used in the hangings of the King's Council Chamber, better known as the Queen's Drawing room.
This room contains several beautiful landscapes by Zuccarelli, three of them being Scripture pieces, one representing "Jacob watering his fleck," while the other two, which are very large, and occupy the whole of the west wall, represent "Issac's meeting" and the "Finding of Mose." It is expected that this will be used as a drawing-room by the King of Hanover, while other portions of the State apartments will be appropriated to the use of the Crown Prince and Princess of Prussia.
In other parts of the Castle suites of apartments are being fitted up with much care and taste, especially those which will be occupied by their Royal Highnesses the Princess and Prince Christian of Denmark, and other members of the same royal family who will be present at the celebration of the royal wedding.
The observed on a lady being presented at the British Queen's drawing room is as follows:

"On getting out of the carriage, everything in the shape of a cloak, or scarf, or even of lace, must be left behind; the train folded carefully over the left arm, and the wearer enters the long gallery at St. James's, where she waits until her turn comes for presentation, she then proceeds to the presence chamber, which is entered by two doors; she goes in by that indicated to her, and, on finding herself in the presence chamber, lets down her train, which is instantly spread out by the lords in waiting with their wands, so that the lady walks easily forward to the Queen.
The card on which the lady's name is inscribed is then handed to another lord in waiting, who reads the name aloud to the Queen.
When she arrives just before her Majesty, she courtesies very low, so low as almost, but not quite, to kneel before the Queen, who, if the lady presented be a peeress or a peer's daughter, kisses her forehead; if merely a commoner, holds out her hands to be kissed by the lady presented who, having done so, rises and making another courtesy to any member of the royal family present, then passes on, keeping her face toward the Queen, and backing out to the door appointed for those to go out of the presence chamber."

The worshipful company of merchant tailors of the fraternity of St. John the Baptist, of the city of London, recently tendered to the Prince of Wales for his acceptance the honorary freedom of that ancient and loyal company, of which his reverend and deeply lamented father, the late Prince Consort, was an illustrious member.
His Royal Highness, in reply, said he had great gratification at receiving the freedom of the company, and expressed his sense of the flattering terms in which the honor was conferred.

The English papers are somewhat exercised in regard to the question how a man may change his name.
Some say only by royal license, others that they acquire a right to a new name by usage.
Then the question comes up what name shall the party on probation use?
If he uses his new chosen name he will be told that he has not acquired it by usage; if he uses his old name he will never be in a position to declare that he has established the required usage at all:

"One case in point is attracting some attention in England.
A man named Buggey wishes to change his name, and, whimsical as it may appear, he chooses the name A. Newman Mr. Buggey is an investigator into names, and furnishes to the Times a host of odd English surnames, founded on wills in the Prerogative Court in Doctor's Commens.
Upon the list are the following: Bab Belly, Boots, Cripple Cheese, Cockles, Dunce, Dam, Drinkmilke, Def, Flashman, Fatt, Ginger, Goose, Reaste, Barehead, Bungler, Bugg, Buggey, Bones, Cheeke, Clod Demon, Vlend, Frogge, Ghost, Greedy, Hagg, Humpe, Holdwater, Headache, Jugs, Jelly, Idle Kneebone Kidney, Lame, Lazy, Leaky, Maypole, Mule, Monkey, Miksopp, Mudd, Muggins Physicke, Pishead, Pot, Poker, Prig, Punch, Proverbs, Quicklove, Quash, Radish, Rompe, Rawbone, Rottengoose, Swette, Spratt, Sheartlitt, Stiff, Squibb, Sponge, Stubborne, Swine, Shave, Skim, Shrimps, Squalsh, Silly, Shoe, Smelte, Skull, Spattle, Shadow, Snags, Spittle, Taleycoate, Villian, Vittels, Vile, Whale."

It appears from the London publication "Who's Who in 1863" that the eldest duke is the Duke of Cleveland, who is 74 years old, and the youngest the Duke of Norfolk, aged 15; the eldest marquis is the Marquis of Lansdowne, aged 82, the youngest the Marquis of Ely, 13; the eldest carl is the Earl of Charlemont aged 87, and the youngest the Earl of Charleville, 10; the eldest viscount is the Viscount Combermere, aged 89, the youngest, Viscount Downe, 18; the eldest baron is Lord Sinclair, aged 94 the youngest, Lord Rossmore, 11, the eldest member of the privy council is Lord Lyndhurst, aged 90, the youngest, Earl Spencer, 27.

During the last few years the unfortunate mode, which came in with the Empire, of reckless expenditure, has been rapidly grinning vogue.
All the world now et le grande monde, et le demit monde, et le quart de monde, and even the bourgeoise, are all alike seized with the mania of living and dressing as if dame Fortune held an income of 100,000 francs at their disposal.

The excessive luxury which dress at the present moment has attained, and which is rarely equal either to the fortune or the position of the parties concerned, proves a source of no little embarrassment.
The Empress's extravagance, as well as her good taste, is undisputed, and, with such incentives to emulate each other, it is not wonderful that half the fine ladies are said to be over head and ears in debt; few of them have ready money in their purses, and, in order to meet the most ordinary necessities of every day life that they have recourse to paying in bills at so many days, weeks, or even months' date.
A friend of mine tells me that her corsetiere had assured her that she had just received from a finely dressed lady a bills for ten francs at three months sight for repairs of articles furnished by her.

div4.p: --The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock M., by Mr. Hunter, of Va. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Sehon of Nashville, Tenn.
Mr. Brown, from the Committee on Military Affairs, reported a bill to increase the pay of Acting Midshipmen in the Navy.

The Senate were informed that the House had passed bills "allowing minors to hold commissions in the army;" refunding to the State of Alabama the amount overpaid by said State on account of the war tax of 1862; for the relief of certain officers and soldiers from the State of Missouri; adopted a resolution of thanks to Gen. Wheeler, &c.; joint resolution of thanks to Gen. Magruder, &c., for action at Galveston, and do, to Gen. W. R. Walker, &c. for good conduct and gallantry in the battles of Pocatallgo and Cosawatchle.
The resolution relative to Gen. Walker was referred to the Committee on Military Affairs; the same course was taken as to the bill for the relief of certain officers and soldiers from the State of Ala; do as to bill to allow minors to hold commissions in the army.
The bill refunding to the State of Alabama the amount overpaid by said State on account of the war tax of 1862 was referred to the Committee on Finance.

The joint resolutions of thanks from the House, relative to Gen. Wm. E. Wheeler and the officers and men of his command, and Gen. Magruder and officers and men, at Galveston, Texas, were referred to the Committee on Military Affairs.
Amendments of House to Senate bill authorizing the issue of bonds for refunding Treasury notes were concurred in and the bill announced as passed.
The Exemption bill came up as the unfinished business, and occupied the attention of the Senate till the hour of adjournment.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock, and was opened with prayer by Rev. Mr. Wise.
Mr. Chilton, of Ala, from the Committee on the Quartermaster's Department, presented the annexed report:

The Committee on the Quartermaster and Commissary Departments and Military Transportation, to whom was referred the resolution of this House instructing them to make special inquiry and report as to any connection, official or otherwise, that Major Frank G. Ruffin, of the Commissary Department, may have had with making, or with the benefits of a contract entered into between the Confederate States and Messrs. Haxall, Crenshaw & Co. for supplies of flour, have had the same under consideration, and have instructed me to report that, after a full and searching investigation, and an examination of all the witnesses who were supposed to be best acquainted with the facts, and after soliciting evidence by giving notice of the time and place of the sessions of the committee to all parties concerned, (copies of which correspondence, together with a memorandum of the proof, are here with submitted) the committee arrived at the conclusion that Maj. Frank G. Ruffin has no connection, either official or otherwise, with the making of said contracts and no interest whatever in the benefits or profits thereof.
On the contrary, the proof conclusively shows that he knew nothing of the fact that any such contract was in contemplation until after it was consummated, being on furlough, by reason of sickness, when it was made.
All which is respectfully submitted.
The report was laid upon the table and ordered to be printed.

The bill reported back from the Military Committee to amend an act entitled "An act for the establishment and organization of a General Staff for the Army of the Confederate States" was taken up and passed.
The bill as passed by the House reads as follows:

Be it enacted by the Congress of the Confederate States. That from and after the passage of this act the rank pay, and allowance, attached to the office of Quartermaster General of the Army of the Confederate States shall be those of a Brigadier General in the Provisional Army.

Mr. Miles, of S. C. from the Committee on Military Affairs, reported back a bill to provide for the arrest of soldiers absent from their commands without leave, and providing compensation to their captors.
This bill was discussed at some length and several amendments agreed to; but without final action upon it, was laid over, and the special order taken up.

Mr. Kenner, of La., moved that the House resolve itself into secret session on the special order, being a bill to provide for funding the currency, and the motion being agreed to, the House went into secret session.
--The Senate assembled at noon. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Moore.

A communication was received from the Executive in relation to the arms transferred from the State to the Confederate Government, in response to a resolution of the Senate.
The communication stated that none of the small arms so transferred have been returned; and, further, that the State does not, and has not, repaired any arms for the Confederate States, the State Armory having been turned over to the Confederate authorities for that purpose.
On motion, the communication was laid on the table, and ordered to be printed.

Committee Bills.--A bill in relation to special county police.
A bill defining citizenship.
A bill repealing an act converting the Northwestern Bank of Virginia, at Jeffersonville, into a separate and independent bank.
A bill allowing John Persons the Sheriff elect of Lee county, further time to qualify, and give the bond of office.
The bill to incorporate the Farmville Insurance Company was reported from committee, with amendments.--The act to legalize certain acts of the County Court of Spotsylvania was reported from its committee without amendments.

The Committee for Courts of Justices reported adversely to the resolution inquiring into the expediency of amending the act of January 24th, 1819, so as to allow John Hankine to sell certain stocks held by him as such and to invest the proceeds in stocks of the Confederate Government, and asked to be discharged from the further consideration of the subject.

Resolutions.--Mr. Dickinson introduced a resolution directing the Committee on Privileges and Elections to inquire into the expediency of enjoining a postponement of the general State election until October, instead of this time now fixed by law. Agreed to.

By Mr. Lewis: Relating to the investment by guardians and others in the stock of the Confederate Treasury.
Agreed to.
The bill to transfer the State Line to the Confederate Government was called up, variously amended, and laid upon the table.

Mr. Brannon moved a reconsideration of the vote by which the bill authorizing the sale of slave convicts was ordered to its engrossment.
The vote was reconsidered, and the bill, with amendments, laid upon the table.
Also the reconsideration of the vote by which the bill increasing the salaries of the Secretary of the Commonwealth, Auditor of Public Accounts, Register of the Land Office, and other officials of the State Government, was ordered to its engrossment and moving the striking out the names of the heads of the several departments included.
Reconsidered and laid on the table, with the first section stricken out.
On motion of Mr. Newman, &c. Senate adj'nd.

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 11 o'clock. Prayer by the Rev. Dr. Doggett.
Mr. M*Camant, from the Committee on Propositions and Grievances, submitted a report relative to the establishing of a public foundry.

Mr. Magruder, from the Special Committee appointed to confer with the Secretary of War, relative to a detail of men to work on the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad, in order to facilitate the transportation of salt, for the benefit of the people of this and other States of the Confederacy, reported that the committee had performed the duty assigned them, and that whilst the rules of the Department were very rigid in regard to details, the Secretary fully concurred with the Legislature in the necessity expressed for providing all proper facilities for supplying the people with salt, and that he would make this an exceptional case, and order the detail asked for accordingly.

Mr. Robertson, of Richmond, submitted a resolution, which was agreed to, for the appointment of a special committee of five to inquire into the expediency of incorporating the Richmond Importing and Exporting Company.
Mr. Mallory offered a resolution providing that after to-day the House shall meet at 10 o'clock, until further ordered.
Objection being made, the resolution lies over.
Mr. Hopkins, from the Committee on Extortion, made further report of testimony taken by them on the subject of extortionate prices, which was ordered to be printed.

On motion of Mr. Hunter the rules were suspended and the report of the Committee of Courts, declaring the present session of the General Assembly not to be a continuation of the session of May, 1862 was called up.
Mr. Mallory moved that the House disagree with the report of the Committee.

The consideration of this report — which assumes that the session of the Legislature held in May last ended with the close of the extra session convened in September by proclamation of the Governor — was briefly discussed, when the previous question was called, and the vote being upon the motion of Mr. Mallory, it was disagreed to — ayes 23, noes 62.
The Committee's report was consequently agreed to.
At 12 o'clock the further consideration of the Tax bill was resumed, and continued until fifteen minutes of three, at which hour.
On motion of Mr. Saunders, of Franklin, the House adjourned.

div3.head: Escape of prisoners
div3.p:
--The following prisoners confined in the city jail, dug out of their cells about 1 o'clock on Tuesday, and traversing the old causeway or gutter under the edifice, made their way to the rear of the building and escaped through the coal hole of the "work-house" department — the members of the City Battalion appointed to watch them having retired under a shed out of sight to avoid the rain which was falling at the time — viz: George W. E. am, charged with forging and passing forged Confederate States Treasury notes; Wm. Reid, charged with stealing a $25 overcoat, belonging to G. R. Howard, in company with John T. Smith; Albert Manning, a swindling substitute agent; Jas. McQuade, charged with the Jarceny of money from Robert Lumpkin; and Samuel Blake, charged with stealing $200 worth of clothing, belonging to Wm. M. Blackford Captain of Engineers on Gen. Jackson's staff.
When the guard happened to look out of their covert they espied several other felons ready to follow the example of their levanting comrades, and stopped them.
The guards who permitted the prisoners to escape were put in confinement for trial by Court-Martial.

div3.head: Man shot.
div3.p:
--A sailor named Fitzpatrick shot a marine named Richardson yesterday evening, between 5 and 6 o'clock, on Main, near 17th street. Both men belonged to the steamer Richmond.
The marine had been sent after the sailor, who had left the ship without permission.
He found him at H. Beckman's restaurant, and had a dispute, which was renewed on the street, and ended by the sailor drawing a pistol and shooting his comrade.
The ball entered just above the nipple of the left breast.
The wound was not considered fatal.
The perpetrator ran into Beckman's and escaped by the rear, clouding pursuit.

div3.head: Railroad accident.
div3.p:
--The down train on the Central railroad, due Feb'y 17th, had a wheel of one of the cars broken when near Anderson's turn out, 30 miles from Richmond, by which accident three of the Orange and Alexandria railroad cars were thrown across the track.
The down mail and other trains running by that point were delayed twenty-four hours. The mail train due in this city at 15 minutes past 6 o'clock Tuesday evening, did not arrive until 7 o'clock last evening.
Passengers on the up mail train yesterday morning were taken from the vicinity of the accident by the down train and conveyed up the road, thus making the connection complete.
The cars that piled themselves across the track were smashed up, but luckily no body was hurt.

div3.head: Lodged in the Penitentiary.
div3.p:
--John McGinness, convicted of stealing a horse from John S. Dorsett, and sentenced to five years in the Penitentiary, and John Boyd, convicted of grand larceny in stealing $28 from O. M. Hancock, and sentenced to two years by Judge Lyons, were conveyed to the Penitentiary on Tuesday evening by the City Sergeant.
When these prisoners were being carried to the City Jail on Tuesday evening, Boyd and McGinness were handcuffed together and walking by the side of Mr. Dudley, John Phelps being between two assistants of the Sergeant, walking in front.
The cortege had gotten to the African Church on its way to the Jail when Boyd adroitly slipped off his handcuffs and McGinnesi ran off — The Sergeant then threw down his umbrella and divested himself of his cloak, and pursued the fugitive, who ran down to the Medical College and turned up Marshall street. After an exciting race of several squares the Sergeant overhauled and recaptured McGinness on Marshall street, near 10th.
During the time pursuit was being made Boyd was secured.
Phelps, alias Dunbar, on the disappearance of his comrade (McGinness) around the corner of the College, took up the Sergeant's cast off cloak and umbrella and conveyed them to the jail, perfectly unmoved by the scene that was enacted in his presence.

div3.head: Arrested for disloyalty.
div3.p:
--Captain Wright, of the detective force, on yesterday arrested a man named John Shanks, formerly of Norfolk, on the charge of disloyalty.
Shanks, who until very recently was in Norfolk, by some process unknown to the authorities, made his way into Richmond.
It is alleged that during his stay in Norfolk he employed himself in selling so called Union badges to negroes belonging to citizens residing in the Congressional district of which Norfolk forms a part.
General Winder ordered him to Castle Thunder to answer the charge.

div3.head: Yankee prisoners.
div3.p: --Two Abolition prisoners were brought to the Libby prison yesterday, viz: Jas. Statts, company H. 1st Michigan, captured at Brentsville, Va., February 14, and Thos. Murray, company M, 1st New York, captured at Wood stone, January 25th.

div3.head: Re-arrested.
div3.p:
--Stephen McNell, who made his escape from Castle Thunder Sunday night, was re-arrested and conducted back to prison yesterday evening.
He was put in for deserting from Capt. Wallace's company, Wise Legion, after joining it as a substitute.

div3.head: Arrival of a flag of truce boat.
div3.p:
--A telegraphic dispatch was received in this city on Tuesday evening by the military authorities announcing the fact that a Yankee flag of truce boat had arrived at City Point with four hundred paroled Confederate soldiers.
None of the latter had arrived in the city up to yesterday evening.

div3.head: Resigned.
div3.p:
--Major-General Gustavus W. Smith, of the Confederate States Army, having tendered his resignation to the President, it was yesterday accepted.
His staff, composed of officers from various States, have started to their several destinations.

div3.head: Prison Items.
div3.p:
--Right deserters were lodged in the military prison of the Eastern District yesterday.
John Melan, a soldier, died in the prison hospital yesterday of typhoid fever.

div3.head: Court Proceedings.
div3.p:
--John Phelps alien Dunbar, convicted of stealing a horse from a Captain in the army, was yesterday arraigned before Judge Lyons for sentence.
When, in reply to the usual question if he had anything to say, he protested his innocence, declaring that he had bought the horse for whose stealing he stood convicted.-- The Judge sentenced him in accordance with the finding of the jury, to two years in the Penitentiary.

A young man named John Orrell, was tried before Judge Lyons for effecting an entrance into the dwelling house of Mrs. Mary A. Allen for the purpose of committing a felony.
He was found concealed in a room in the third story of the house.
The jury sent him to jail for thirty days for the imputed offence.

James M. Elmore was tried in Judge Lyons's Court yesterday for being concerned with John Phelps alias Dunbar in stealing two horses belonging to Capt Henderson and a comrade.
Counsel for defence paraded a bill of sale for the horse alleged to be stolen, given by a party said to have sold the same to Elmore.
The jury were, on their retirement, unable to agree on a verdict.
Hustings Court.--There was not much business done in this Court on yesterday.

div3.head: From New Orleans
div3.p: --The Advertiser and Register has the following special dispatch from Jackson, Miss., dated the 15th:

The New Orleans Picayune, of the 13th, is received at Tangipahoe.
It says the Delta has been suppressed, on account of objectionable articles, and is superseded by the Kra, a new paper.
It is reported that Banks was shot at from a window.
The Delta says an officer carelessly threw some explosive cartridges from a window, which exploded.
The Bank of Louisiana was burned on the 13th inst. The Delta mentions a rumor that Butler was shot by J. H. Bouligny.
The Federal are making good headway at Yagoo Pass, but ample efforts are believed to be making to arrest their further progress.

div3.head: By Williamson & Co., Aucts.
div3.p: Trustee's Sale of Real Estate in the town of Fulton at Auction.--By virtue of a deed of trust executed by Richard Robb and his wife Elizabeth A Robb to the subscriber, dated the 3d day of August, 1854, and recorded in the Clerk's office of Henrico County Court, being requested so to do by the parties interested, I will proceed to sell, on Thursday, the 19th day of February, at 4 o'clock P. M., upon the premises, the property conveyed by said deed, viz: Those three lots of Land lying and being in the county of Henrico, in the town of Fulton, near the city of Richmond and designated on the plat of said town, (a copy of which is on file in the office of the Clerk of Henrico County Court.) as lots Nos 30, 31, and 36, in square No. 19, and bounded as follows, to wit: Lots Nos 10 and 31 being situated at the Northwest intersection of Orleans and Erin streets, fronting together 60 feet on the North side of Orleans street, and running back, between parallel lines, 115 feet, and lot No. 36 being likewise situated on the North side of Orleans street, commencing at the distance of 90 feet East of Fulton street, fronting 30 feet on Orleans street, and running back, between parallel lines, 115 feet.
The title is believed to be good, but selling as Trustee, I will convey only such title as is vested in me.

Terms--Cash.
T. C. Burns, Trustee.

Sale by Williamson & Co., Auct'ra.
fe 3
Postponement.--The above sale has been postponed till Tuesday, 24th inst, when it will come off at the same hour and place.
By Harvey, Hunt, James & Co., Auct'rs, [Warehouse Virginia st, under the Tobacco Exchange]
We will hold our next auction sale on Friday, Feb'y 20th, commencing at 10 o'clock, at which time we will offer a large and desirable invoice of
Blockade Goods,
Comprising a splendid assortment of
Dry Goods,

Manufactured and Smoking Tobacco,
and Groceries generally.
Parties wishing to avail themselves of this opportunity will please send in their goods or samples early, so that they may be arranged for exhibition.

div3.head:
Thos. T. Owens, Auctioneer
[no. 202 Main street.]
div3.p: Notice.--I have taken the large ware-rooms No. 202 Main street, formerly occupied by the Southern Express Company, where I will carry on a general.
Auction and Commission Business.
The patronage of my friends and the public generally are respectfully solicited.
I will attend particularly to the sale of House-hold Furniture of families declining house-keeping, at their residences, or at my sales rooms, where the goods can be exhibited to a great advantage.
I will also attend to the sale of Stock at the horse lot on Council Chamber Hill, and elsewhere.

div3.head: Four Tracts of Land for Sale.

list.item:
1.
A tract of 705 acres on the edge of Lunenburg and Charlotte, and only five miles from Keysville Depot, over a road which is level and otherwise excellent both winter and summer.
The improvements are a plain but comfortable frame Dwelling, a story and a half high, with two spacious rooms below, two smaller rooms above, with a porch in front and one in the rear, and a store-room at one end of the front porch; 7 or 8 Barns; Stable, Carriage-house, Lumber-house, two Corn Cribs, Dining room or office in yard, Kitchen, Smoke-house, Meal-house, four negro Cabins, (two double,) Garden, and an excellent Orchard of healthy young apple trees, from which about 100 gallons of brandy have been made in one season.
Wood is abundant and convenient, as more than one half the tract is in original forest.
The tract is well watered also, and has about 50 acres of creek or branch flat, and about 100 acres of upland, recently cleared, fresh and productive.
The fences are in first rate condition.
There are 23 barrels of Corn in one of the cribs, and on the tract 4 stacks of Oats, 3 of Fodder, about 2 tons of Bay, and some Shucks, all of which any purchaser of the land can have at neighborhood market rates.
A fine opportunity to purchase is afforded to refugees or others desiring a home, as this tract will be sold on very low and advantageous terms to any one who will shortly apply, and immediate possession will be given.

2. A tract of 87 acres, just at Meherrin Depot, in Prince Edward county.
This tract is all in original forest, with no improvements thereon except a comfortable Log Cabin.
The wood upon it, which can be sold to the railroad at a fair price, renders it valuable.
The soil is of fair average quality.

3. A neat residence at or near Charlotte C. H., a story and a half high, with four rooms.--There is also a Kitchen, good Well, Stable, &c., Garden, Orchard, 23 acres of good arable land, under good fences, attached, and about 2 acres of wood land.
For a more minute description of this tract refer to Mr. Davidson, of the firm of Davidson & Chockley, Commission Merchants, Richmond.

4. The Methodist Parsonage at Charlotte C. H. The Dwelling is a story and a half high, with four rooms, besides a dry, spacious room in the basement.
There is also a Dining-room in the yard, Kitchen, Stable, &c., and 7 or 8 acres of good land attached.
These two village residences will each comfortably accommodate a small family, and can be bought at a low figure.
Apply to

div3.closer:
Isaac R. Watkins,
Attorney at New, Charlotte C. H. fe 18--2t

div3.head: Danville Female College, Danville Va.
div3.p:
--Season begins February 23, ends July 4, 1863.
The best teachers in all departments.
Location safe and healthy.
Rates low. No pains spared for the comfort of the pupils.
For circulars, address me at Farmville, Va., until the 13th of February.

div3.head: By James M. Tayler & Son, Auct's.
div3.p: Valuable Improved and Unimproved Real Estate at the Northwest intersection of Broad and Henry Streets, at Auction.--At the request of Mrs. C. Sternaw, we will sell upon the premises on Thursday, the 26th day of February, commencing at 4 o'clock P. M., the valuable Real Estate located as above, in the following order, viz:

list.item:
1st.
The valuable Store and Dwelling located at the northwest intersection of Broad and Henry streets, for a number of years occupied by Mr. C. Sternaw, dec'd. It is built of brick, contains six good rooms, together with the usual conveniences.
Its location adapts it for a business stand or dwelling.
The lot fronts on Broad street 30 feet, and runs back 100 feet to a wide alley.

2d.
A large brick Tenement, nearly adjoining on the west how in the occupancy of Mrs. Sternaw.
It contains four good rooms above the cellar, is arranged for a store or dwelling, and supplied with the usual outbuildings.
This is also considered a first rate business stand.

3d. Two small framed Tenements, immediately in rear of the first-mentioned house.
They have several good rooms each, and are adapted for small-sized families.
The lots are of the usual size.

4th. Three handsome vacant Lots, lying between the two stores, fronting 30 feet each and running back 150 feet to an alley.
Upon these Lots are a large quantity of choice grape vines, fruit trees, etc. They will be divided or sold in the gross, as may be desired.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 4 and 8 months for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
The purchaser to pay the taxes for 1863.

div3.head: Trustee's Sale of Real Estate on Church Hill and in Port Mayo, at Auction.
div3.p:
By virtue of a deed of trust executed by John McDonald and wife to the subscriber, dated the 15th day of June, 1863, and recorded in the Clerk's Office of Henrico County Court, being thereto requested by the parties interested, I will proceed to sell on Saturday, the 28th day of February, upon the premises, the property conveyed by said deed, to wit: 1st, commending at 4 o'clock P. M., a lot of Land lying in Henrico county, near the city of Richmond, known as "Church Hill," fronting 62 feet on the Eastern line of 25th street, at its intersection with the Northern line of K. street, and running back eastwardly and at right angles to 25th street 125 feet to an alley 12 feet wide, and thence southwardly along the Western line of said alley 62 feet to the Northern line of K. street, and thence along the Northern line of K. street 125 feet to the beginning; and at 4½ o'clock P. M., that lot of Land lying in the county of Henrico, in the town of Fulton, fronting 180 feet on the South line of Nicholson street, and running back with parallel lines 110 feet to an alley in common, 10 feet wide, being lots Nos. 12 and 13 in Square No. 19 in the plan of Fulton.
Terms--At sale.

div3.head: Desirable farm, or market garden,
div3.p:
on the Deep Run Turnpike, or Broad street continued ½ miles from the city, at Auction.--We will sell, upon the premises, on Tuesday, the 24th day of February, commending at 4 o'clock P. M., a very desirable farm, or market garden, on the North side of the Deep Run Turnpike, or Broad street continued, 8½ miles from the city, and now in the occupancy of Mr. Wm Bennett.
It contains eight acres of superior gardening land most of which is set in choicest vegetables, including a large asparagus bed. The improvements consist of a comfortable framed dwelling, containing 4 rooms and a passage, a barn, stable, and other buildings, all in good order and well enclosed, together with a well of excellent water.

Terms.--One third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
The purchaser to pay the taxes for 1863.
Possession will be given in 15 days from day of sale.
div3.closer:
Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Auct's.
The above can be treated for privately. fe 18

div3.head: Handsome Lot in the plan of Gulston, near to Buchanan Spring, on Hancock street, at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell upon the premises, on Saturday, the 21st day of Feb'y, commencing at 4 o'clock P. M., a handsome let on the east side of Hancock street, near to Buchanan Spring.
It fronts 31 feet and runs back 160 feet.
Will also be sold a lot of Timber, consisting of flooring, Joice, and other articles for building purposes.
Terms.--One-half cash; the balance at 4 months, for a note, with interest added, and satisfactorily secured.

div3.head: Administrator's Sale of 86 acres of Land, in Henrico county, on the Deep Run Turnpike, at Auction.
div3.p:
--As Administrator of John Ford dec'd, I shall proceed to sell, upon the premises, on Monday, 2d day of March, 1863, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., the tract of Land on which the said John Ford resided, on the Deep Run Turnpike, in Henrico county, seven miles west of the city of Richmond, and adjoining the lands of Messrs R. J. A. Smith, John W. Alley, and James Shepherd.
It contains 86 acres of land, well improved.
The improvements consist of a comfortable Dwelling, with several rooms; Barn, Stable, and other necessary out-houses, together with an excellent orchard of the choicest Fruit Trees.
Terms--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
div3.closer:
John A. Hutcheson,
Late Sheriff of Henrico co and as such
Adm'r of John Ford, dec'd.
Sale by J. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.
P. S.--The above will be sold at the risk and cost of Jas. H. Ford who has failed to comply with the terms of sale.
J. A. Hutcheson, Adm'r. fe 17

div3.head: Excellent Brick residence at the Northwest corner of Clay and 3d streets, at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell upon the premises on Wednesday, the 25th February, commencing at 4 o'clock, a very excellent Brick Residence located as above, now in the occupancy of Mr. Wm. Garrett.
It contains eight comfortable rooms, a brick kitchen with four rooms, stable and carriage house, smoke-house, &c., all in first rate order.--The house is supplied with gas and water.
The lot fronts 33 feet and runs back 150 feet to an alley 15 feet wide.
Possession will be given in thirty days from the day of sale.

Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
The purchaser to pay the taxes for 1863.

div3.head: Real Estate at Rocketts, together with personal property, at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell, upon the premises on Monday, February 23d, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., a House on the north side of Elm street, now in the occupancy of Mr. Dolan.
It contains four comfortable rooms, and is well arranged.
The lot fronts about 20 feet, and runs back the usual depth.

Also, a vacant Lot adjoining, upon which are three stables.
Also, a vacant Lot on the opposite side of the street, fronting about 60 feet, and running back as above.
Also a lot on Poplar street, having the usual front, and running back 205 feet to the York River railroad.
Also, 13 Lots on the hill in rear of the city Gas Works, each fronting 31 feet and running back 150 feet.
After the sale of the real estate will be sold 45 Milch Cows, 8 Horses, 12 Hogs, and 10,000 weight of Clover, Hay, etc.

Terms.--For the real estate, one-third cash; the balance at 4 and 8 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
For the personal property, cash will be required.

div3.head: By Williamson & Co., Aucts.,
div3.p: [No. 192 Main st.]

Smith and others, I shall proceed to sell at public auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 3d day of March, 1863, beginning at 4 o'clock P. M., the property in said decree mentioned, continuing of a lot of ground, with a wooden dwelling-house and other improvements thereon, fronting 30 feet on the East line of 2d street, between Lee and M. sts, running back 150 feet.

Terms--One-fourth cash; balance at 6, 12 and 18 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, and title retained until all the purchase money be paid and a conveyance directed by the Court for the purchaser, at his option, may pay the whole purchase money in cash.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchaser.

div3.head: By Geddin & Apperson, Auctioneers.
div3.p:
The large, Elegant and Handsome Estate, called "Rocky Mills," on the South Anna river, in Hanover county, 20 miles Northwest of Richmond, for Sale at Auction in Richmond. --Will be sold at our auction rooms, on Tuesday, the 3d March, 1863, at 12 o'clock M, that valuable farm called Rocky Mills, in Hanover county, on the South side of the South Anna river, 10 miles from Ashland and 12 miles from James river, and within 20 miles of Richmond, containing 1,041 acres of land, with buildings of the best kind, which have cost over $25,000. About 300 acres are in timber and place, and the balance is cleared.
Lands rolling and well adapted to the usual crops.
Also, Dr. Swan's old Mills, with — acres of land, along Gold Mine creek, and likewise a timber tract of 302 acres in front, running down to near Beren Meeting-House.

Gentlemen are invited to ride up and examine this desirable estate; for, as a summer residence or permanent location, seldom such a chance presents itself.
The grounds about the mansion- house and the garden are among the best in the State.
The owner (A. W. Nolting, Esq) will be pleased to unaccommodated and lodge gentlemen going up to examine the property.
Terms.--One-third cash; balance at 1 and 2 years, with interest, and well secured.

Plats will be exhibited at our office as soon as received, and any further information given.
In the meantime, we earnestly invite those who may wish to purchase such an estate, to examine the premises, which will be shown by Mr. Nolting.

div3.head: The beautiful Suburban farm,
div3.p:
in the village of Bowling Green, called "Summer-field," containing 24½ acres, one mile East of Richmond, for Sale at Auction.--At the request of Mr. Alex McKeever, (who has changed his purpose to remove to it,) we shall, at auction, on the premises, on Saturday, the 21st of February, 1863, at 4 o'clock P. M., sell the beautiful country seat located as above, into the residence of Hon. John M. Botts, situated in Bowling Green, about one mile East of Richmond.
The tract contains 21½ acres, which will be divided into two parcels, so as to sell with the mansion house 14½ acres, and 10 acres with the lot in rear.
The improvements consist of an excellent brick dwelling, newly papered, containing 7 rooms, besides kitchen, brick stable, smoke-house, etc., with a fine garden, and an excellent young orchard, and two pumps of water near the dwelling.
Possession given at once.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 1 and 2 years, for bonds bearing interest payable half yearly, secured by a trust deed; or all cash, at the option of the purchaser.

div3.head: Two Handsome Lots in Manchester.
div3.p: on the West side of Allen, between Hull and Rainbridge streets, for Sale at Auction.--At the request of Patsey Brooks we shall sell at auction on the premises, on Friday, the 20th of February, 1863, at 5 o'clock P. M., two handsome Lots, located as above, each fronting 37 feet, running back 132 feet.

Terms.--One-third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchaser.

div3.head: Commissioner's Sale of valuable Real Estate in the City of Richmond.
div3.p: --As Commissioner appointed by a decree of the Circuit Court of the city of Richmond, pronounced on the 7th February, 1863, in the case of Carnell's against, Carnell, &c., I shall proceed to sell at public auction, on the premises, in the order advertised, on Thursday, the 26th February, 1863, commencing at 3½ o'clock P. M., the following valuable Lots and Tenements, viz:
A lot on the North side of Catherine, between Monroe and Henry streets 30 by 80 feet, with a double brick kitchen thereon.

2d.
A lot, with two brick and stuccoed tenements, on Monroe street, near to Brook Avenue, 31½ feet by 130 feet.

3d.

Peter street.

4th.
A lot, with frame Dutch roof tenement, on the North side of Duval street, near the above, 30 by 157 feet.

5th.

6th.

7th.

Terms.--One-fourth cash; balance at 6, 12 and 18 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, and title retained till all the purchase money is paid and a conveyance directed by the court; or all cash at the option of the purchaser.
The taxes for this year to be paid by the purchaser.

div3.head: The beautiful country seat called "Chantilly,"
div3.p:
on the Deep Run Turnpike, 3 miles West of Richmond, containing 218 acres, for Sale at Auction. --Will be sold, at auction, on the premises, on Thursday, the 20th February, 1863, at 12 o'clock M. the beautiful country seat located as above, now owned by Mr., Hugh M. Hutcherson, and recently by his father, the late Ambross Hutcherson.
It contains 218 acres, and will be so divided as to give the Mansion House tract 79 acres, and the balance will be divided into four lots, one containing 18 acres, one containing 17 acres, one containing 50 acres, and one containing 54 acres. Some of the lots are well wooded, and all of them are handsomely located, embracing beautiful building sites.
The neighborhood is an excellent one.

Terms.--One-third cash; balance at 1 and 2 years, for bonds, bearing interest, secured by a trust deed; or all cash at the option of the purchasers.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchasers.

div3.head: Large Brick Store and Dwelling
div3.p:
on Main and Pear streets, near Messrs Hardgrove's Factory, for Sale at Auction.--At the request of Mr. James Kinnaird, we shall sell at public auction, on the premises, on Friday, the 10th February, 1863, at 4 o'clock P. M., the very valuable property located as above.
The improvements consist of a large Brick Store and Dwelling, covered with slate, now occupied by Mr. Geo Ehming, together with brick kitchen, also covered with slate.
The lot attached to the dwelling has a front on the West line of Main street of 65 feet, running back about 241 feet, and having a rear breadth of 168 feet.

Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
The taxes and insurance for 1863 to be paid by the purchaser.

The foregoing real estate was sold at auction on the 30th January, 1863, and purchased by John Raredan, who having failed to comply with the terms of said sale, it will be resold at his risk and costs.

div3.head: Very valuable building Lot,
div3.p:
on the West side of 19th, between Grace and Bread streets, for Sale at Auction.--Will be sold at auction, on the on Friday, the 20th Feb., 1863, at 3½ o'clock, P. M., a most beautiful lot, located as above, fronting 25 feet and running back 122 feet to an alley 20 feet wide.
This is one amongst the most beautiful lots now in market and in a most desirable and attractive neighborhood.

Terms--One-third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchaser.

div3.head: Commissioner's Sale of a half-acre Lot,
div3.p: No. 28, in Duval's Addition, at the corner of St Stephen and Charity sts.--As Commissioner of the Circuit Court of Richmond appointed by a decree entered on the 12th of February, 1863, in the case of Coleman against Belt, &c., I shall proceed to sell, at public auction, on the premises, on Wednesday, 25th Feby, 1863, at 4 o'clock P. M., the above valuable half-acre Lot, fronting 144 feet on the west side of St Stephen street, running back on the south side of Charity street 120 feet, and adjoining the residence of Capt Thos C. Epps.

Terms--One-third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, and title retained until the further order of the Court.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchaser.
div3.closer:
R. H. Coleman, Com'r.
Sale conducted by Goddin & Apperson, Auctioneers. fe 14

div3.head: Remittances to the Dispatch.
div3.p:
--We have made arrangements with the Southern Express Company by which all money for subscription, advertising, or job work, can be sent at our risk.
The money to be sent should be enclosed in an envelope, directed to the "Richmond Dispatch, Richmond, Virginia," and seated with war, writing the subscriber's name, post-office, and amount sent on the outside.
Deliver the same to any agents of the Southern Express Company, and take his receipt.
Send a letter to the office of the Dispatch by mail, advising us of the date when sent.
Our agents will observe carefully these directions, and follow them.

div3.head: Type Wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper with to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of Nonpareil or Agate Type.
The highest price will be paid.

div3.head: Mr. Seward's attempt to Deceive France.
div3.p: Mr. Seward plainly holds to the creed that "a lie well told and stuck to is as good as the truth." In his dispatch of 6th February to Mr. Dayton, which is directed to be laid before the French Government, he says the Confederate States "retain only the States of Georgia, Alabama, and Texas, with half of Virginia, half of North Carolina, two-thirds of South Carolina, half of Mississippi, and one-third respectively of Arkansas and Louisiana."The remainder of the Confederacy, he claims, has been re- established under the flag of the Union."

Such is the statement of facts presented to Mr. Drouyn de L'Huys!
It is hardly less insulting to his intelligence than the answer given to his recommendation for a conference between the belligerents — that a mode already exists for such conference, by our acknowledging the authority of the Yankee Government, and sending Senators and Representatives to Washington.
At the same time that the French Minister of Foreign Affairs receives Mr. Seward's statement he will probably also receive from Mr. Mercier full and accurate accounts of the state of the war, and from Mr. Paul, and the other French Consuls of the South, reports of the situation not less trustworthy, and accompanied by files of Southern newspapers.
With these materials in hand, derived from honorable and impartial sources, M. Drouyn de L'Huys takes up his maps and addresses himself with the quick apprehension of a great mind to slit the truth of Mr. Seward's declarations.
Of Virginia Mr. Seward claims half.
The French Secretary finds from his reports that while the Yankees hold the Northwest and the Kanawha Valley, the extreme north of the Valley to Winchester, and a few of the more northern and eastern counties, the Confederacy holds the capital firmly nearly the whole of the railroads, and in fact about two thirds of the State--that this possession has been maintained after four gig antes attempts at invasion have met bloody repulse, and that at last the enemy's army on the Rappahannock, demoralized and dispirited, has retreated, apparently in despair, from the hopeless task of subjugating an unconquerable people.

Of North Carolina, also, Mr. Seward claims half as subjugated.
Three- fourths of this State lies west of the Weldon and Wilmington Railroad, as a glance at the map will show.
From the beginning of the war until now not a single Yankee hireling has put his foot prints west of that railroad.
Except for a period of ten days that road has been constantly employed, and cars run through, carrying our troops and munitions of war, and it is now daily used for that purpose.
East of this road the Yankees hold, by a liberal estimate, one half of the remaining fourth of the State, and even there the people continue faithful and stead-fast in devotion to the Southern Confederacy. Mr. Seward's falsehood concerning North Carolina the one upon Virginia.

In South Carolina, Mr. Seward claims one-third as in Yankee occupancy.
What must be the disgust of the Emperor and his Minister to find that at no time have the enemy held any part of that State West or North of the Charleston and Savannah Railroad, and that the road referred to has been regularly and daily used by the Confederate Government!
A simple inspection of the map will show that this road does not cut off one-twentieth part of the State, and yet it embraces all and more of South Carolina soil than the Yankees have ever held even for a moment.

Georgia, Mr. Seward does not claim; nor Alabama, Texas, too, he magnanimously admits is ours.
But of Mississippi he claims one-half!
Sometime ago the Yankee army of invasion advanced to a point somewhat South of the Tallahatchie river, while our line of defence was the Yallabusha.
The enemy held most of the country North and West of the Tallahatchie, which comprised, perhaps, a fifth part of Mississippi.
Since then their lines have been much withdrawn, and it would be too much to say that they hold now a sixth part of that State.
This is sufficient, however, for Mr. Seward's purposes of fabrication. "Give the devil an inch and he will take an ell."

Of Louisiana, according to Mr. Seward, the enemy hold two-thirds.
In fact, they hold only the banks of the Mississippi up to Port Hudson and the extreme Southeastern part of the State; at the outside hardly a tenth part of Louisiana.
This is shown conclusively by the cannon of Port Hudson and by the fact that the Confederacy own and work an almost inexhaustible salt mine within twenty miles of the sea coast and less than eighty from New Orleans.

Of Arkansas, Mr. Seward claims two thirds.
Not less than four-fifths are and have been always in undisturbed occupancy of the Confederacy.
Tennessee and Florida are claimed bodily by Mr. Seward.
Of the latter, not a twentieth part is in Yankee occupancy.
As to Tennessee, our Government holds East Tennessee firmly; our army, under Gen. Johnston, is encamped in the very heart of Middle Tennessee, at Tallahoma, confronting the enemy, who does not dare to advance; and our cavalry, under Van-Dorn, Forrest, Wheeler, and Morgan, ream almost at will over West Tennessee, Middle Tennessee and Central Kentucky, burning bridges, capturing posts, cutting off detachments, and destroying the stores and munitions of the enemy. --All these facts were well known to Mr. Seward when he penned the falsehoods we have exposed.
What could have been his aim!
It could hardly have been the hope of successfully deceiving the Emperor and M. Drouyn de L'Huys, for they are men accustomed to look beneath the surface, and to act on more reliable information than what is supplied by the dispatches of the Yankee Premier.
Nor are these impudent fabrications explained by the natural desire to make out a case which would see the wounded vanity of a people stung with rage and shame at the defeats of Fredericksburg and Vicksburg.
No, it is John Barleycorn who must answer for these perversions of well known truths.
Seward has for some time past taken to drink.
Animated with the courage thus inspired, he has thought it a fine thing to insult the French Emperor with statements of fact which he must know to be false, and by deliberately informing him, in response to a grave proposition, that the Southern States can "confer" with the North by grounding their arms, submitting to the Union, and by sending representatives to the Yankee Congress.
A respectful answer, truly, to a humane offer of mediation between two belligerents whose strife has brought so much suffering to the civilized world!

div3.head: Fighting for the negro.
div3.p:
One of the few indications of reason and common sense which has been given by any party in the United States since this war begun is the resolute purpose manifested by the Conservatives to resist the emancipation policy of Abraham Lincoln.
They seem clearly to comprehend that "fighting for the negro" is the most asinine of all human occupations, and would be, if successful, a triumph over Northern commerce not less than Southern independence.

There was, before the war, some honest ignorance in the North of the true condition and character of the negro; but the war has introduced and his mission to all mankind.
He is no longer an object of mystery and romance.
It familiarity has not bred contempt for him as yet in the eyes of the Black Republicans, it has sickened their Democratic allies to the very bottom of their stomachs.
They are beginning to analyze the black diamonds, and ascertain their real worth.
They are discovering that they are valuable in the right place, but that place is not in the free States, nor where they can come in competition with while labor.
They perceive that the negro only works upon compulsion; and that unless he is made to work, and that in cotton, rice, and tobacco, Northern conservation, allies Northern commerce and must go to destruction.
It is surprising that other nations, such as England, have not long ago made the same discovery.

Are they awake or asleep that the developments of such a war as this add nothing to their stock of knowledge of negro character!
Instead of an element of weakness, do they not seem that they are a corner-stone of a nation's strength in war?
Is it not better that black barbarians should, by subjection to the mild restrictions of Southern servitude, be made the most useful and productive class of human laborers, than that they should roam the dirty alleys and cellar of the North in fifth and freedom?
Is it not better to keep the manufactures and commerce of England alive by their industry, then?

div3.head: A lesson for Lincoln.
div3.p: The Yankee historian, Prescott, in his History of the Conquest of Peru, says that the monarchs of that country, in carrying on war, "allowed their troops to commit no unnecessary outrage on persons or property. 'We must spare our enemies,' one of the Peruvian princes is quoted as saying, 'or it will be our loss, since they and all that belongs to them must soon be ours.' It was a wise maxim, and, like most other wise maxims, founded equally on benevolence and prudence."

The Gorilla Administration at Washington may learn a lesson of both humanity and prudence from the sovereigns of semi civilized Indians, more than three centuries ago. Perhaps the complacent manner in which the historian criticises the ferocity of the Spaniards, in their efforts to convert and conquer, may be somewhat moderated by the examples of greater ferocity than that even of Spaniards, which has been furnished since his history was written by the invading zealots of his own Massachusetts, in the midst of the idolized nineteenth century.

div3.head: General McClellan.
div3.p:
There must be an awful dearth of military genius in the United States, when the restoration of McClellan to the chief command of the Army of the Potomac is urged by leading Northern journals as the only means of crushing the rebellion.
If ever a man had been tried in the balances and found wanting, it is that same G. B. McClellan.
Old Wingfield Scott, after being allowed only three months and fifty thousand men, was thrown overboard because he did not succeed in his "On to Richmond;" whilst McClellan, with a whole year for preparation, and a hundred and fifty thousand men, was whipped out of the Peninsula like a thieving bound, and yet his friends complain because he was removed, and insist that nothing but his restoration will restore "the Union." If the Union leans upon G. B. McClellan, it leans upon a broken read.
Whatever confidence his own men may repose in him after his Peninsula experience, there is no terror in his name to the dwellers upon the Chickahominy.

div3.head: Correction.
div3.p:
--The quotation of Confederate bonds in yesterday's paper at $101½ and int, was a misprint.
The correct quotation is $100½, payable in new currency.

div4.p: On the 17th inst, at Dr. Wesley Wright's, in Caroline county, by the Rev. B. H. Johnson, Lieut A. M. Frayser, of the 47th Virginia reg't, and Miss Mary E. Haley, of Caroline co, Va. *

On Tuesday, February 17th, at St. Paul's Church, by the Rev. Dr. Minnegerode, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Norwood, Richard de Trivills, Jr., of Charleston, S. C, to Ella, youngest daughter of the late Wm. Mitchell, Jr, of this city.
Charleston papers please copy. *
At the residence of her grandmother, in Fredericksburg, on the 5th inst, of typhoid pneumonia Anna Bilbeck, only daughter of J. W. and Susan E. Powell, aged 6 years 8 months and 21 days.

lg.l: Ere sin could blight, or sorrow fade,
The opening bud to Heaven conveyed,
Farewell, dear Anna, thou hast left us,
We thy loss doth deeply feel;
But 'tis God who hath bereft us,
He can all our sorrows heal.

div4.head: Obituary
div4.p: Died, at Elmwood, Halifax co., the residence of her father, Col. Henry Carrington, on the 12th of February, 1863, Mrs. Agnes Morton Din Widdie, wife of Wm. Dinwiddie, Esq. of Albemarle.

She never recovered from an attack of measles in the spring of 1861.
The disease settled on her lungs, resulting in consumption, with its long train of tedious and painful sufferings.
But the Lord enabled her, by His grace, to submit to His will with meekness and resignation, and to bear a clear, bright beautiful, and triumphant testimony to the power and preciousness of faith in Him. With the words, "My Saviour ! my Saviour !" on her lips, her spirit passed gently into His presence, where "the weary are at rest." *

A reward of $30 will be paid for his arrest, and delivery to some proper officer.
