near King William Court House, Va.,
February 18th, 1863
div3.p: All absentees of this corps will report to me immediately, or I shall advertise them as deserters.

div3.head: Two hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p: --The following Negroes runaway from the Carbon Hill Mines, in this county, on the 15th inst., viz:

Harry Williams, a dark-brown negro, 5 feet 9½ inches in height, not very stout, good looking, about 32 years old varicose veins in both legs, leg most affected, lately purchased from Green county, N. C.

Ben Williams, dark brown, 5 feet 6 inches high, very stout, round face, very likely, about 25 years old, just recovered from a serious attack of pneumonia, lately purchased from Jones & Slater, and came from Green county, N. C.

Jim Lawrence, a black negro, 5 feet 3 inches in height, remarkably broad across the shoulders, and powerfully made, about 30 or 32 years old, good teeth, countenance indicating shrewdness and rascality a shot mark in the right leg, lately purchased, and came from near Goldsborough, N. C.

George Holt, a brown negro, 5 feet 8 inches high about 25 years old, good teeth, eyes rather close together, not stout, has a scar from a severe wound inside of his left hand, was a foreman on one of the North Carolina railroads for four years, comes from Goldsborough, N. C.

Lyall Griffin, (or Rblas,) a light brown negro, 5 feet 7 inches in height, round shoulders, heavy brown, slim figure, and indifferent looking, was under medical treatment when he left for a chronic disease is about 32 years old, came from near Goldsborough, N. C.

Jim is no doubt the leader of the party, and is probably endeavoring to reach the Yankee lines near Goldsborough.
They carried an axe with them.

For the apprehension and delivery to me in Richmond of either of these negroes I wall pay $10 if taken in this city or county; $20 if taken is an adjoining county; or $10 if taken up thirty miles from Richmond in any direction.

div3.head: Forty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
-- my farm near Keysville, in Charlotte co. Va, on Sunday the 15th instant, my negro man George Braxton of Dickinson, Hill & Co, as the property of Thos A. Lacy, New Kent co, Va, in December last.
His wife lives near Mr. Lecy's, where, I suppose, he is making his way. He is a little under the medium height black, has full whiskers, speaks rather indistinctly; had on when he left a Yankee blue overcoat and vest, black hat and patched pants.
He is about 35 years old. I will give $30 reward for him if taken between my house and Richmond, and brought to my house, or $10, if taken in Richmond or beyond that place, and lodged in jail in Richmond so that I get him again.
div3.closer:
Thos L. Ruedlay,
Keysville Va. fe 19--5t*

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay $50 for the arrest and lodgment in a safe jail of my man George, if taken out of the city of Richmond or county of Chesterfield, or $20 reward if taken in those limits.
He left my house, in Manchester, on Saturday last, about 12½ o'clock P. M. He is about 6 feet high 23 years old, brown color, and weighs about 100 pounds. He had on when he left a brown frock coat, and was well dressed generally.
He carried a bag of clothes with him. He came from near Danville, and is probably trying to get back.
He may hire himself to work in some camp, or try to get off on the canal.
He had on a good black hat.

div3.head: Twenty Dollars reward
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the return of a small negro boy named Peter, or for any information given so that I can get him. He left my house, on Union Hill, about the 25th of January.
It is very likely he may report himself free, and apply to some of the hospitals or camps around Richmond for employment.
He has a scar under his chin from and one also over one eye, and is about 14 years of age.

div3.head: Ran away
div3.p:
--From the undersigned, about ten days since, my negro boy George.
For his apprehension and delivery to Mr. Robest Lumpkin a reward of $25 will be paid.
George is about 17 or 18 years old of a dark brown color, tolerably stout built, small head and face, walks slowly and lazily; when spoken to replies slowly with a downcast look; had on when he left dark clothes, much worn, and an old straw hat; usually wears a short, shaggy, black overcoat.
He lived the latter part of last year at Mr. H. J. Smith's, near Fairfield, and was again hired there this year but ran off. He is probably secreted by some one in the city, or may be at some of the camps near the city.
If caught beyond the county lines, and delivered here to Mr. Lumpkin and editional reward of $25 will be paid.
div3.closer:
J. R. Allen
Corner Main and 11th sts, fe
